__data__.text: In the early days of radio broadcasting, two significant stations were WEAF in New York City and WJZ in Newark. During the consolidation phase, RCA, a radio manufacturer, purchased WEAF from AT&T. WJZ, owned by shareholder Westinghouse, was a rival station that also functioned as the main station for a loose network.

In 1923, WJZ was moved from Westinghouse to RCA and relocated to New York City. Initially, WJZ had served as a research base for Westinghouse's technological advancements in voice- and music-grade audio transmission. Previously, WEAF, owned by AT&T, had functioned as a lab for Western Electric, AT&T's manufacturing and supply division, which produced transmitters and antennas. Both stations facilitated the Bell System's development of audio transmission technologies over short and long distances through wireless and wired methods. The establishment of WEAF in 1922 provided a center for these research and development efforts.

The establishment of WEAF in 1922 not only introduced a regular schedule of radio programs with early commercial sponsorships but also served as a crucial research-and-development hub, similar to WJZ's role for Westinghouse, for the Bell System's advancements in audio transmission technologies.

The creation of WEAF in 1922 led to the introduction of sponsored radio programs and the development of audio transmission technologies. Following this, WEAF formed connections with WJAR and WCAP, marking an early instance of networked broadcasting. RCA, the parent company of WEAF, aimed to share programming and transmit audio between cities. After obtaining a license for WRC in 1923, RCA tried to use low-quality telegraph lines for transmission, as AT&T denied outside companies access to their superior phone lines.

AT&T, which owned superior phone lines, initially denied outside companies like RCA access. However, after their early attempts to transmit audio using low-quality telegraph lines faced issues such as interference, AT&T decided that WEAF and its network were not aligned with their primary goal of offering telephone services. Consequently, AT&T sold WEAFS to RCA in 1925, along with the right to lease AT&T's phone lines for network transmission, leading to the establishment of the Red and Blue Networks.

After selling WEAF and its phone lines to RCA, AT&T led to the creation of the Red and Blue Networks. RCA, having spent $1 million, acquired WEAF and WCAP, closing down the latter and combining facilities with WRC. In late 1926, RCA, along with its parent company General Electric and Westinghouse, established the National Broadcasting Company (NBC) as a new division, with ownership shares of 50%, 30%, and 20%, respectively.

NBC, a division of RCA, General Electric, and Westinghouse, began broadcasting in November 15, 1926, after RCA's acquisition of WEAF and WCAP. For around a year, WEAF and WJZ, the primary networks, were run concurrently under NBC. On January 1, 1927, NBC separated their marketing approaches, designating the "Red Network" for commercially sponsored entertainment and music, while the "Blue Network" mainly aired non-sponsored broadcasts, such as news and cultural programs.

After NBC's formation in 1926, they operated WEAF and WJZ networks concurrently until designating the "Red Network" for commercial programs and the "Blue Network" for non-sponsored broadcasts in 1927. The color designations may have originated from the pushpins' colors or double-ended pencils. NBC expanded to the West Coast with the NBC Orange Network in 1927 and the NBC Gold Network in 1931.

(Note: The NBC Orange Network was also known as the Pacific Coast Network, and the NBC Gold Network was also known as the Pacific Gold Network.)

Following NBC's division of their networks by content in 1927, the Orange Network (also known as the Pacific Coast Network) broadcast Red Network programs to the West Coast, while the Gold Network (also known as the Pacific Gold Network) transmitted Blue Network content. Initially, the Orange Network repeated Red Network shows for West Coast stations at KPO in San Francisco. In 1936, Orange Network affiliates joined the Red Network, and the Gold Network became part of the Blue Network. Concurrently, NBC relocated its operations to 711 Fifth Avenue in Manhattan, which Floyd Brown designed.

After NBC's division of networks by content in 1927, the Orange Network and Gold Network broadcast Red Network and Blue Network content to the West Coast and other regions, respectively. Initially, the Orange Network rebroadcast Red Network shows for West Coast stations at KPO in San Francisco. However, in 1936, Orange Network affiliates joined the Red Network, and the Gold Network became part of the Blue Network.

In the meantime, NBC expanded its operations to a shortwave radio network, the NBC White Network, in the 1930s. In 1930, General Electric, the parent company of NBC, faced antitrust charges, leading to its divestment of RCA. Subsequently, the newly independent RCA signed leases to move its corporate headquarters to the Rockefeller Center in 1931, an arrangement facilitated by John D. Rockefeller Jr., the founder and financier of Rockefeller Center, and RCA president David Sarnoff. NBC outgrew its Fifth Avenue facilities in 1933, prompting the move to Rockefeller Center.

In 1933, RCA, now independent from General Electric, became the primary tenant at the RCA Building (later named GE Building, now Comcast Building) in Rockefeller Center, housing NBC's production studios and RKO Pictures theaters. The famous NBC chimes, with the sequence G-E-C', were introduced over WSB, a Red Network affiliate, after years of development, featuring a second inversion C-major triad. This move was facilitated by John D. Rockefeller Jr. and RCA president David Sarnoff as NBC had outgrown its previous facilities.

In 1931, NBC adopted the now-famous NBC chimes, which were first heard over WSB during a Georgia Tech football game broadcast. These chimes, featuring a specific C-major triad sequence (G-E-C'), were later approved as the first audio trademark in the US. This development occurred when NBC, having outgrown its previous facilities, moved to the RCA Building in Rockefeller Center, where it became the primary tenant, housing NBC's production studios and RKO Pictures theaters. This transition was made possible with the support of John D. Rockefeller Jr. and RCA president David Sarnoff.

In 1931, NBC introduced its distinctive C-major triad chimes, which became the first audio trademark in the US. An extended version, known as "the fourth chime," was played during crucial events like World War II and disasters, gaining significance during urgent situations. This innovation coincided with NBC's relocation to the RCA Building in Rockefeller Center, supported by John D. Rockefeller Jr. and RCA president David Sarnoff.

In 1932, Richard H. Ranger, founder of Rangertone, mechanized the NBC chimes to serve as a low-level, consistent signal for NBC and AT&T engineers at switching stations. This mechanism functioned as a cue for engineers to switch between the Red and Blue network feeds.

The NBC chimes, initially automated by Richard H. Ranger in 1932, were developed as a consistent signal for engineers at NBC and AT&T to switch between network feeds, rather than being a reference to General Electric. The three-note sequence, G'-E'-C', is still utilized by the NBC television network, including in NBC News' theme music.

The NBC chimes, created by R.H. Ranger, were initially used by NBC and AT&T for synchronizing network feeds. They later became publicly known and were adopted by the Baltimore & Ohio Railroad for signaling meal times. The Blue Network was later rebranded as ABC due to a complaint by the Mutual Broadcasting System to the FCC about limited access to the radio market controlled by NBC and CBS. The NBC chimes are still used in NBC News' theme music.

In 1938, the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) launched probes into the monopolistic consequences of network broadcasting, focusing on NBC's dominance in audiences, affiliates, and advertising. A 1939 FCC report confirmed NBC's control, leading to an order for RCA to sell either NBC Red or NBC Blue. After the Mutual Broadcasting System's appeals failed, RCA chose to sell NBC Blue in 1941, anticipating a negative ruling on its own appeal.

In 1941, RCA decided to sell NBC Blue, then officially named NBC Blue Network, Inc., if its appeal was unsuccessful. The networks officially separated on January 8, 1942, with NBC Red operating as "NBC" and NBC Blue referred to as "Blue" or "Blue Network" on-air, legally named Blue Network Company, Inc. The sale was executed by investment firm Dillon, Read & Co.

Following its separation from NBC Blue in 1942, NBC Red was referred to as "NBC" during broadcasts. Dillon, Read & Co. made a $7.5 million bid for NBC Blue, which was turned down by RCA's president and NBC's executive. After losing a Supreme Court appeal in 1943, RCA sold Blue Network Company, Inc. to the American Broadcasting System, owned by Edward J. Noble, for $8 million.

After purchasing Blue Network Company, Inc. from RCA for $8 million, Edward J. Noble gained rights to the Blue Network name, leases on landlines, New York studios, two-and-a-half radio stations (WJZ, KGO, and WENR), contracts with actors, and deals with around 60 affiliates. In order to adhere to the FCC's radio station ownership rules, Noble sold his existing New York City radio station, WMCA.

Following the purchase of Blue Network Company, Inc. from RCA, Edward J. Noble rebranded it as "American Broadcasting Company" (ABC) in 1945, after acquiring the necessary rights from George B. Storer. This change was made to establish a distinct and improved identity for the network. Noble also sold his personal New York City radio station, WMCA, to comply with radio station ownership regulations. Meanwhile, NBC emerged as a prominent broadcaster, hosting numerous popular programs and personalities, marking radio's golden age.

During the 1940s, NBC flourished as a leading radio broadcaster, housing numerous popular personalities and shows that characterized radio's golden age. High-profile figures such as Bing Crosby, Al Jolson, Jack Benny, Edgar Bergen, Bob Hope, Fred Allen, and Burns and Allen had shows on NBC. Moreover, the network supported the formation of Arturo Toscanini's NBC Symphony Orchestra and broadcast various programs like Vic and Sade, Fibber McGee and Molly, The Great Gildersleeve, One Man's Family, Ma Perkins, and Death Valley Days.

In the 1940s, NBC, a leading radio broadcaster, featured many popular personalities and shows, including Bing Crosby, Jack Benny, and Arturo Toscanini's NBC Symphony Orchestra. Meanwhile, CBS began to compete by letting stars create their own production companies, which proved financially beneficial for its talent. During this time, NBC stations were dominant, with strong signals reaching vast distances, while stars and programs often switched networks when contracts ended.

During the late 1940s, numerous popular radio personalities, such as Jack Benny, Edgar Bergen and Charlie McCarthy, Burns and Allen, and Frank Sinatra, left NBC for CBS as their contracts ended, taking advantage of CBS's policy of allowing stars to form their own production companies. This shift was driven by the increasing trend of stars moving to television, with NBC's Milton Berle's Texaco Star Theater becoming a significant hit. Meanwhile, NBC's Arturo Toscanini continued his NBC Symphony Orchestra's broadcasts on both radio and television.

In the late 1940s, many radio stars, like Jack Benny and Edgar Bergen, moved from NBC to CBS, which permitted them to establish their own production companies. This transition was mainly motivated by the growing trend of celebrities transitioning to television, with NBC's Milton Berle's Texaco Star Theater gaining popularity. Simultaneously, NBC's Arturo Toscanini continued to air his NBC Symphony Orchestra's performances on both radio and television. A notable example of this simultaneous broadcast (or simulcasting) included two historic firsts: the initial complete telecast of Beethoven's Symphony No.

(Note: The summary is conceptually similar to the original text, but it may not be significantly shorter due to the importance of maintaining all propositions and context.)

In the late 1940s, as radio personalities like Jack Benny and Edgar Bergen moved from NBC to CBS to create their own production companies, NBC's Arturo Toscanini continued to broadcast his NBC Symphony Orchestra's performances on both radio and television. Notably, two of these concerts were historic firsts: the complete telecast of Beethoven's Symphony No. 9 and Verdi's Aida (featuring Herva Nelli and Richard Tucker), presented in concert form rather than with staging and costumes. In response to the shift of talent to CBS and the rise of television, NBC introduced The Big Show in November 1950 to maintain classic radio and compete with CBS's Sunday night lineup.

The Big Show, a 90-minute variety program hosted by Tallulah Bankhead, debuted on NBC in 1950 to preserve traditional radio and rival CBS's Sunday lineup. It offered refined comedy and drama, attracting distinguished performers such as Fred Allen and Ella Fitzgerald. However, despite critical acclaim, the show's popularity waned due to the growing number of television viewers.

The Big Show ran for two years, but NBC suffered a loss of approximately $1 million as they could only sell ads for the middle half-hour of each episode. This unsuccessful project marked NBC's final significant investment in radio programming, which concluded with the launch of Monitor in 1955, led by NBC President Sylvester "Pat" Weaver, who was known for his innovative television programs.

Monitor, a radio program launched by NBC President Sylvester "Pat" Weaver, was a continuous weekend show that presented a mix of music, news, interviews, and features, similar to the format of vintage radio. Lasting from 1955, it featured famous television personalities such as Dave Garroway, Hugh Downs, Ed McMahon, Joe Garagiola, and Gene Rayburn. To keep the classic radio spirit, it included segments from Jim and Marian Jordan, known as Fibber McGee and Molly, Peg Lynch's comedic dialog Ethel and Albert, and satirist Henry Morgan. This program marked NBC's final significant investment in radio, wrapping up their radio programming ventures.

For a few years, Monitor was a successful radio program that combined various elements, similar to vintage radio. However, from the mid-1960s, local stations, particularly in larger markets, were hesitant to deviate from their established formats for non-conforming network programming. A notable exception was the weekly series, Toscanini: The Man Behind the Legend, which celebrated the renowned conductor's NBC broadcasts and recordings for several years, starting in 1963. Eventually, Monitor concluded its 20-year run in 1975, leaving NBC network radio with only hourly newscasts, news features, and the Sunday religious program, The Eternal Light. This signified the end of NBC's significant radio programming ventures.

NBC introduced the NBC News and Information Service (NIS) in 1975, offering extensive news coverage for local stations considering an all-news format. The service, available on WRC in Washington and NBC's owned-and-operated FM stations in New York, Chicago, and San Francisco, provided up to 55 minutes of news per hour, signifying NBC's attempt to adapt to the changing radio landscape after Monitor's conclusion.

After launching the NBC News and Information Service (NIS) in 1975 to cater to local stations exploring an all-news format, NBC faced financial challenges. Despite attracting numerous subscribing stations, NIS failed to demonstrate profitability by the fall of 1976. Consequently, NBC notified its affiliates of the service's termination, which took effect on May 29, 1977, due to unsustainable financial prospects.

After closing NIS in 1977 due to financial struggles, NBC introduced The Source in 1979, a secondary network that supplied news and short features to FM rock stations with modest success. NBC also initiated TalkNet, a satellite-distributed national talk radio program focusing on personal advice, which included shows by Bruce Williams, Bernard Meltzer, and Sally Jessy Raphael. Although TalkNet didn't gain high ratings, it played a significant role in advancing the national talk radio format.

NBC's TalkNet, though not a ratings hit, significantly contributed to the development of national talk radio. It provided free programming for affiliated struggling AM stations, enabling them to air local ads and avoid production costs for local content. However, this trend raised concerns about increasing network and syndicator control over radio content. Eventually, GE, which had reacquired RCA, decided to sell RCA's non-broadcast assets and NBC's radio divisions.

Following NBC Radio's struggle to maintain high ratings, the network sold its radio division, including NBC Radio Network, The Source, NBC Talknet, NBC Radio Entertainment, and leases to its facilities, to Westwood One (which already owned the Mutual Broadcasting System) for $50 million. This sale occurred after an unsuccessful attempt to sell the entire radio unit to Westinghouse Broadcasting. This acquisition allowed Westwood One to expand its reach and influence in the radio industry, while also raising further concerns about the growing power of syndicators and networks over radio content.

In the wake of NBC Radio's ratings struggle, the network sold its radio division to Westwood One in 1988, which then went on to acquire additional radio stations from Emmis Communications, Westinghouse, and Susquehanna Radio Corporation by 1989. As a result, NBC Radio News relocated to Mutual's Arlington, Virginia facility, with engineering operations and the affiliate relations department following suit. In 1992, further consolidation occurred as Mutual and NBC newscasts began joint production during overnights and weekends, and both networks started airing identical sportscasts throughout the weekend. This series of transactions contributed to Westwood One's expansion and influence in the radio industry, as well as increasing concerns about the growing power of syndicators and networks over radio content.

Following NBC Radio's sale to Westwood One in 1988 and their subsequent acquisitions of radio stations, NBC Radio News and engineering operations moved to Mutual's Arlington facility. By 1992, both networks combined newscasts and sportscasts. In 1994, Westwood One's acquisition of Unistar Radio Networks from Infinity Broadcasting led to Infinity buying 25% of Westwood One, making them the largest shareholder and gaining control. These events illustrate the growing consolidation and influence of syndicators and networks in the radio industry.

After Infinity's acquisition by Westwood One and their subsequent purchase by Westinghouse Electric Corporation in 1996, Infinity became the parent company of CBS/Westinghouse Broadcasting, which resulted in CBS Radio Network being managed by Westwood One. The Arlington newsroom for Mutual and NBC was closed in 1998, and CBS Radio News started producing "Mutual" and "NBC" newscasts from New York. These occurrences further highlight the increasing consolidation and influence of syndicators and networks in the radio industry.

After the closure of the Arlington newsroom in 1998, CBS Radio News began producing "Mutual" and "NBC" newscasts from New York, which were then restricted to weekday morning drive (ET) starting from April 17, 1999. Following this, Westwood One started offering CNN Radio newscasts to remaining NBC affiliates during other time slots. Westwood One later collaborated with NBC News to launch NBC News Radio on March 31, 2003, featuring one-minute newscasts on weekdays anchored by NBC and MSNBC talent, while phasing out the Mutual name. These events emphasize the growing influence and control of syndicators and networks in the radio industry.

In 2004, Westwood One started distributing a Meet the Press audio simulcast, which continues today. Westwood One was bought out in 2007 and merged into Dial Global in 2011, adopting its name. Dial Global discontinued CNN Radio newscasts in 2012, making NBC News Radio full-time and attracting most CNN affiliates. Additionally, Dial Global and NBC Sports introduced NBC Sports Radio as a joint venture in September 2012. These developments illustrate the increasing dominance of syndicators and networks in the radio industry.

In 2013, Cumulus Media acquired Dial Global, which led to the revival of the Westwood One name and its merger with Cumulus Media Networks. Around the same time, NBC Sports Radio was shut down, ending its 24/7 programming in 2018 and closing completely in 2020. Additionally, following a content-sharing agreement between Cumulus and CNN, NBC News Radio ceased operations in December 2014. These events further highlight the growing power of syndicators and networks in the radio industry.

After NBC Sports Radio and NBC News Radio ceased operations in 2018 and 2014 respectively, iHeartMedia began producing "NBC News Radio"-branded newscasts under a licensing agreement with NBCUniversal. This move underscores the increasing influence of syndicators and networks in the radio industry. It is worth noting that NBC was long associated with David Sarnoff, who leveraged the network to promote consumer electronics, including the introduction of all-electronic television at the 1939-40 New York World's Fair.

In 1939, President Franklin D. Roosevelt became the first U.S. president to appear on television, using NBC's network during an event at the New York World's Fair, which was held at a time when NBC, under David Sarnoff's leadership, was closely linked to consumer electronics promotion, including the introduction of all-electronic television. This historical event is documented with an existing photograph from the telecast, which is housed at the David Sarnoff Library. This anecdote highlights the long-standing relationship between NBC and significant developments in television technology.

In 1939, during the New York World's Fair, President Franklin D. Roosevelt made the first US presidential TV appearance on NBC's W2XBS Channel 1. The broadcast, transmitted from the Empire State Building, reached approximately 1,000 viewers within a 40-mile radius. Coinciding with this event, RCA started selling four TV models in New York City department stores, advertised in local newspapers, emphasizing NBC's role in promoting television technology and its connection to consumer electronics.

Before the 1939 New York World's Fair, DuMont Laboratories and other companies had already introduced home TV sets in 1938, preceding NBC's official television launch in April 1939. This move aimed to capitalize on the anticipated growth in television technology and its consumer electronics applications.

After the introduction of home TV sets by DuMont Laboratories and others in 1938, NBC entered the television scene in 1939 to leverage the growing potential of TV technology. Later that year, NBC started broadcasting camera feeds of professional football and baseball games in the New York City area, marking several milestones in TV history. A significant event occurred on January 12, 1940, when NBC transmitted its first "network" program, a play called Meet The Wife, from its W2XBS studios in Rockefeller Center. The live signal was then received by W2XB/W2XAF (now WRGB) in Schenectady through the air and retransmitted to the Capital District.

In the late 1930s, NBC expanded its television broadcasts to Philadelphia and Schenectady, alongside its existing New York City transmissions. These expansions led to the groundbreaking telecast of the Republican National Convention in Philadelphia in 1940, which was simultaneously transmitted to both New York City and Schenectady stations, representing the most ambitious NBC television "network" program prior to the war.

The expansion of NBC's television broadcasts to Philadelphia and Schenectady in the late 1930s resulted in the first multi-city network program, the 1940 Republican National Convention transmission. However, RCA's efforts to promote television sales in New York from 1939 to 1942 were not very successful, as the high cost of sets and limited appealing content led to only a few thousand sales, mostly to public places for viewing specific events.

The experimental phase of television ended in 1941, with the FCC approving commercial broadcasts and NBC's W2XBS in New York becoming WNBT, the first licensed commercial station. During this period, only a few thousand TV sets were sold, primarily in New York, due to their high cost and limited appealing content. A notable event was President Franklin D. Roosevelt's live television appearance at Madison Square Garden in October 1940, which was transmitted to the New York City area. The first paid television advertisement was aired by WNBT on July 1, 1941, marking the beginning of commercial television in the United States.

The first paid television advertisement in the US was aired by WNBT on July 1, 1941, introducing the commercial television era. This ad, featuring a Bulova watch test pattern modified as a clock with the company's logo, was shown before a Brooklyn Dodgers baseball telecast. At that time, TV sets were expensive and limited, with only a few thousand sold mainly in New York. The experimental phase of television had just ended, with FCC approving commercial broadcasts and W2XBS becoming WNBT, the first licensed commercial station. Notable events during this period included President Roosevelt's live appearance on TV and the increasing popularity of television.

The first commercial week of WNBT included various programs such as The Sunoco News, amateur boxing, tennis championships, USO programming, a spelling bee-type game show called Words on the Wing, and some feature films. A test broadcast of the game show Truth or Consequences, sponsored by Lever Brothers, also aired. Before the introduction of paid television advertisements, non-paid TV advertising had been experimentally in place since the 1930s.

In the initial phase of television commercials, before paid advertisements were introduced, NBC aired non-paid commercials during early TV broadcasts. An instance of this occurred during the first televised Major League Baseball game between the Brooklyn Dodgers and Cincinnati Reds in 1939, where NBC granted each of the Dodgers' primary radio sponsors the opportunity for a commercial spot.

During the early phase of television commercials, NBC broadcast non-paid ads during initial TV shows, such as the first Major League Baseball game in 1939. Announcer Red Barber promoted products like Ivory Soap, Mobilgas, and Wheaties by holding up the product, wearing a filling station cap, and preparing a bowl of cereal, respectively. Commercials were restricted until the U.S. joined World War II, when broadcasts were reduced. After the war, NBC ramped up its services in anticipation of post-war full-time programming.

Prior to the end of World War II, NBC started transmitting a select number of programs regularly from New York City to affiliated stations in Philadelphia and Albany/Schenectady, starting in 1944. The first of these shows was The Voice of Firestone Televues, a television adaptation of the long-running NBC radio program The Voice of Firestone, which had been airing since 1928. This marked the beginning of weekly scheduled broadcasts from New York City to these two locations.

The Voice of Firestone Televues is regarded as the first regularly scheduled program of the NBC television network, which started airing in 1944. Additionally, "The War As It Happens" was also introduced in 1944 and became the first news program to be broadcast regularly in multiple cities, including Schenectady and Philadelphia. On V-E Day, WNBT transmitted extensive news coverage and remote broadcasts from various locations in New York City.

The first regularly scheduled NBC program, "The Voice of Firestone Televues," began airing in 1944, followed by the first regularly broadcast news program, "The War As It Happens." On V-E Day, WNBT provided extensive news coverage and remote broadcasts from different NYC locations, promoting the event through direct-mail to TV set owners. A camera atop the Hotel Astor captured celebrating crowds, symbolizing early television growth after the war, with NBC's line-up expanding from four initial post-war stations.

The 1947 World Series, featuring the Yankees and Dodgers, boosted local television sales in the New York area. As more stations were added along the East Coast and Midwest via coaxial cable, NBC experienced growth in the post-war 1940s and early 1950s, culminating in the first transcontinental telecasts in September 1951. This period marked NBC's success in the emerging medium of television.

During the late 1940s and early 1950s, NBC Television gained prominence due to the addition of stations along the East Coast and Midwest via coaxial cable, resulting in the first transcontinental telecasts. A significant factor in NBC's success was the emergence of television's first major star, Milton Berle, and his Texaco Star Theatre. Under the leadership of innovative president Sylvester "Pat" Weaver, NBC introduced popular shows such as Today, The Tonight Show, and Wide Wide World, as well as network-produced motion pictures and periodic 90-minute network "spectaculars". These initiatives solidified NBC's leading position in the television industry.

In the early 1950s, NBC, under the guidance of Sylvester "Pat" Weaver, produced motion pictures for television and the live 90-minute series Wide Wide World. However, these initiatives ended in 1955 due to a disagreement with chairman David Sarnoff, who then appointed his son Robert Sarnoff as president. During this time, NBC also commissioned Italian-American composer Gian Carlo Menotti to create the first opera for television, Amahl and the Night Visitors, which premiered in 1951 and told the story of a disabled shepherd boy who is healed after meeting the Three Wise Men and offering his crutch to the newborn Christ Child.

The opera "Amahl and the Night Visitors," created by Gian Carlo Menotti for NBC, became a yearly tradition on the network from 1951 to 1966, but NBC stopped broadcasting it due to a conflict with Menotti. However, the relationship was reconciled by 1978, leading to a new production filmed in the Middle East and broadcast in color. Meanwhile, CBS had started airing color television programs, but their system was not compatible with the existing black and white TVs.

In summary, "Amahl and the Night Visitors" was a successful television opera that aired annually on NBC until a dispute in 1966, but the rift was mended by 1978, resulting in a new color production. During this period, CBS introduced color television, but it was incompatible with black and white sets.

Following a brief, unsuccessful attempt by CBS to air color broadcasts that were incompatible with black and white TVs, CBS discontinued their color system. This created an opportunity for RCA's compatible color system to be accepted as the standard in the US, which the FCC approved in December 1953. Soon after, NBC was prepared to provide color programming using this newly approved system.

After the FCC approved RCA's compatible color system in December 1953, NBC promptly prepared to offer color programming. They started transitioning to color broadcasts in 1954 and aired their first full-color series, The Marriage, in the summer of that year. A significant milestone was reached in 1955 when NBC presented a live color production of the Broadway musical Peter Pan, which was the first broadcast of its kind and featured the original cast, including Mary Martin as Peter and Cyril Ritchard as Mr. Darling/Captain Hook.

Following the FCC's approval of RCA's color system, NBC quickly arranged to introduce color programming. In 1955, they achieved a major milestone by airing a live, color broadcast of the Broadway musical Peter Pan, which starred Mary Martin as Peter and Cyril Ritchard as both Mr. Darling and Captain Hook. This groundbreaking broadcast garnered the highest television ratings of its time.

After the successful, highly-rated color broadcast of Peter Pan in 1955, NBC restaged it live within ten months and later turned it into a standalone special in 1960, using videotape to eliminate the need for live performances. Following this, NBC established California National Productions (CNP) in 1956 to handle merchandising, syndication, and NBC opera company operations, initiating their involvement with the production Silent Services.

In 1957, NBC decided to separate the opera company from CNP, which was simultaneously negotiating with MGM Television to manage distribution of their series. Meanwhile, NBC's owned-and-operated Chicago station, WNBQ (now WMAQ-TV), made history as the first U.S. television station to transmit at least six hours of color broadcasts daily.

In 1959, NBC introduced a color television version of The Bell Telephone Hour, which was a radio program, and it ran for nine more years until 1968. Then, in 1961, NBC proposed a deal to Walt Disney to obtain the rights to his anthology series, suggesting to produce it in color. This summary conveys the main points of the original text, including the programs, their duration, and the shift to color broadcasting.

In 1961, while Disney was negotiating a contract renewal with ABC for his anthology series, then named Walt Disney Presents, ABC's president, Leonard Goldenson, admitted they couldn't match NBC's proposal due to insufficient color broadcasting capabilities. Consequently, Disney partnered with NBC, which started broadcasting the series in color under the title Walt Disney's Wonderful World of Color in September 1961.

In 1961, Disney switched from ABC to NBC for better opportunities, leading to the renaming and color broadcast of Walt Disney Presents as Walt Disney's Wonderful World of Color on NBC. Although many Disney shows on ABC were filmed in color, they were first aired in black-and-white due to ABC's limitations. NBC, having superior color broadcasting capabilities, started airing these shows in color. By 1963, a significant portion of NBC's prime time schedule was presented in color, but some popular series, like The Man from U.N.C.L.E., still premiered in black-and-white during their first season. The Rose Bowl telecast in January 1962 was NBC's first color broadcast of a college football game.

In 1965, NBC had transitioned to broadcasting 95% of its prime time schedule in color, labeling itself "The Full Color Network," despite rival networks being slower to adopt an all-color lineup. Shows like I Dream of Jeannie and Convoy were among the few exceptions still airing in black-and-white on NBC. The other networks fully committed to color broadcasts during prime time in the 1966-67 season, following NBC's lead.

In 1964, NBC commissioned Universal Studios to create the first television movie, "See How They Run," which was broadcast in October, followed by "The Hanged Man" in November. Later, in November 1965, NBC introduced "Days of Our Lives," the first soap opera to air in color, demonstrating their pioneering efforts in color television production. By the 1966-67 season, other networks had followed NBC's lead in committing to color broadcasts during prime time.

Despite the success of NBC's initial television movies in 1964, they didn't produce another one for two years. In 1967, NBC secured the broadcast rights for the film "The Wizard of Oz" from MGM, after CBS, which had previously aired it in color since 1956, declined to pay the increased fee. This move marked NBC's continuous innovation in color television production.

After CBS, which previously aired "The Wizard of Oz" in color, declined to pay the raised fee for its broadcast rights, NBC obtained them in 1967, reflecting their commitment to color television production. As color broadcasts became common by that time, the film was just one of many NBC telecasts in color. Notably, NBC aired The Wizard of Oz without a hosted introduction and edited it slightly to accommodate more commercials.

In the late 1960s, NBC started broadcasting "The Wizard of Oz" in color after CBS declined to pay the increased fee for its rights, demonstrating the networks' shift towards color television. Although NBC made minor edits to the film to air more commercials, it consistently attracted high ratings due to limited viewing options before the VCR era. From 1968 to 1976, NBC annually aired the movie, until CBS decided to reacquire the rights in 1976, recognizing their mistake in losing such a popular program. This period saw significant changes in major television networks' programming practices.

During the late 1960s and early 1970s, major television networks, including NBC, CBS, and ABC, recognized the need to target younger audiences as baby boomers reached adulthood. These networks decided to discontinue many long-running shows that attracted older viewers, like NBC's The Bell Telephone Hour and Sing Along With Mitch, to appeal to the youth demographic that advertisers coveted.

In the late 1960s and early 1970s, major networks, such as NBC, CBS, and ABC, identified adults aged 18 to 49 as their primary target audience, focusing on those not nearing retirement. They adjusted programming to better align with contemporary American society, sometimes targeting specific age groups like 35-45, 18-25, or 18-35. This shift aimed to attract younger viewers and shed the 1950s mentality in television.

In the beginning of the 1970s, NBC experienced initial success with various popular shows, such as Adam-12, Rowan & Martin's Laugh-In, Ironside, The Dean Martin Show, and The Flip Wilson Show, which helped them maintain their strong position at the start of the decade.

In the early 1970s, NBC flourished with popular shows, but faced a slump in the decade's middle despite successful new series and ongoing hits. Notably, Disney's ratings plummeted when CBS scheduled 60 Minutes against it on Sundays at 7:00 p.m.

During the 1975-76 season, under the leadership of President Herbert Schlosser, NBC attempted to draw a younger audience by airing expensive movies, miniseries, and specials. However, this strategy not only failed to attract the targeted 18-34 demographic but also repelled older viewers. Consequently, none of the new prime-time shows introduced in the fall of 1975 survived, each falling short against established competition. This was a particular challenge for NBC, as its popular shows from the early 1970s had given way to a slump in the decade's middle, despite successful new series and ongoing hits. Notably, Disney's ratings plummeted when CBS scheduled 60 Minutes against it on Sundays at 7:00 p.m.

In the 1975-76 season, NBC, led by President Herbert Schlosser, tried to appeal to a younger audience by broadcasting costly movies, miniseries, and specials. However, this approach not only failed to attract the desired 18-34 demographic but also alienated older viewers. As a result, none of the new prime-time shows introduced that fall were successful. This was a significant challenge for NBC, as its popular early 1970s shows had declined in popularity, even with successful new series and ongoing hits. One bright spot for NBC was the introduction of the innovative late-night comedy/variety show, Saturday Night, later renamed Saturday Night Live in 1976. After the season, Schlosser was promoted to executive vice president at RCA, and NBC, in a desperate move, recruited Fred Silverman from highly-rated ABC to reverse its fortunes.

After joining NBC, Fred Silverman struggled to revive the network's fortunes, with many of his new shows failing to gain traction. Notable exceptions included CHiPs, Barbara Mandrell and the Mandrell Sisters, Diff'rent Strokes, The Facts of Life, Real People, and the miniseries Shōgun. However, his tenure was marked by several high-profile failures, such as Hello, Larry, Supertrain, Pink Lady and Jeff, season six of Saturday Night Live, and The Waverly Wonders. These shows often performed poorly in ratings, and some were even outperformed by programs that Silverman had previously approved during his time at CBS and ABC.

While Fred Silverman was attempting to revive NBC's ratings with new shows, many of them underperformed, including Hello, Larry, Supertrain, Pink Lady and Jeff, season six of Saturday Night Live, and The Waverly Wonders. Notably, some of these shows struggled in ratings compared to programs that Silverman had previously greenlit during his tenure at CBS and ABC. Moreover, several long-standing NBC affiliates switched networks in cities such as Atlanta, Bakersfield, Baltimore, Baton Rouge, Billings, Brownsville, Charlotte, Columbia, Dayton, Decatur, El Dorado, Eugene, Fargo, Fort Smith, and Green Bay, which further exacerbated NBC's challenges during Silverman's time at the network.

During Fred Silverman's tenure at NBC, several local affiliates, including those in Fort Smith, Green Bay, Indianapolis, Jacksonville, Knoxville, Marquette, and Minneapolis-St. Paul, switched networks, contributing to NBC's difficulties.

Under Fred Silverman's leadership at NBC, numerous local affiliates, including stations in Jacksonville (WTLV), Knoxville (WATE-TV), Marquette (WJMN-TV), Minneapolis-St. Paul (KSTP-TV), Medford (KTVL), Odessa (KMID), Panama City (WMBB), Rapid City (KOTA-TV), San Diego (KGTV), Savannah (WSAV-TV), Schenectady (WRGB), Sioux Falls (KSFY-TV), Temple (KCEN-TV), Tyler (KLTV), Waterbury (WATR-TV), and Wheeling (WTRF-TV), decided to switch networks, mainly to ABC, which led to NBC facing challenges.

During Fred Silverman's tenure at NBC, many local affiliates, such as stations in Jacksonville, Knoxville, Marquette, Minneapolis-St. Paul, Medford, Odessa, Panama City, Rapid City, San Diego, Savannah, Schenectady, Sioux Falls, Temple, Tyler, Waterbury, and Wheeling, switched networks, primarily to ABC. This shift occurred because ABC had significantly improved its standing, rising from last place to become the leading network during the late 1970s and early 1980s. Meanwhile, WBAL-TV, KERO-TV, KFSM-TV, KTVQ, KVAL-TV, WRGB, and WTRF-TV joined CBS, and WATR-TV became an independent station under the new WTXX calls, later turning into a CW affiliate WCCT-TV. Initially, ABC had contemplated partnering with WBAL. NBC faced challenges due to these defections.

During Fred Silverman's time at NBC, numerous local affiliates, including stations in cities like Jacksonville, Knoxville, Marquette, and others, switched networks to ABC due to its rise in popularity from last place to the leading network. ABC had initially considered partnering with WBAL, but WBAL declined because of ABC's poor-performing evening newscasts. Most of the defected stations were VHF, with a few exceptions being UHF stations such as WAAY, WATR, KLAA, and KERO. Later on, WSB and WSOC became ABC affiliates. This shift caused challenges for NBC as it faced defections to both ABC and CBS.

During Silverman's tenure at NBC, numerous local affiliates, including VHF stations and some UHF stations, switched to ABC due to its growing popularity. WSB-TV and WSOC-TV, both owned by Cox Media Group, became ABC affiliates, while WIIC-TV in Pittsburgh, also owned by Cox, remained with NBC due to its lower ranking compared to CBS and ABC affiliates in the area. This shift led to challenges for NBC as it experienced defections to both ABC and CBS.

During Silverman's time at NBC, several of its affiliates, including VHF and some UHF stations, moved to ABC due to its rising popularity. Notably, WSB-TV and WSOC-TV, both under Cox Media Group, became ABC affiliates, while WIIC-TV in Pittsburgh, owned by Cox, stayed with NBC because of its lower ranking compared to CBS and ABC affiliates. This shift caused difficulties for NBC as it faced defections to both ABC and CBS. In this context, it's worth mentioning that a station previously owned by Group W (now CBS) and bought from DuMont by Westinghouse in 1954, made the controversial decision not to affiliate with NBC, causing a long-lasting strained relationship between NBC and Westinghouse.

During Silverman's tenure at NBC, various affiliates, including VHF and certain UHF stations, switched to ABC due to its growing popularity, causing challenges for NBC as it experienced defections to both ABC and CBS. This shift led NBC to affiliate with UHF stations in several markets, such as San Diego, Fort Smith, Charlotte, Knoxville, and Jacksonville. Among these, KNSD in San Diego eventually became an NBC-owned station, while in Knoxville, NBC moved back to a VHF station in 1988 when it switched to the then-CBS affiliate WBIR-TV. This overall movement resulted in a strained relationship between NBC and Westinghouse, which had previously owned a station that declined NBC's affiliation offer, causing tension that lasted for years.

Silverman's time at NBC was marked by affiliates switching to ABC and CBS, causing challenges for NBC. The network responded by affiliating with UHF stations in various markets, including San Diego, Fort Smith, Charlotte, Knoxville, and Jacksonville. Tension arose between NBC and Westinghouse due to a declined affiliation offer. In Wheeling, NBC improved its affiliation by partnering with WTOV-TV, outperforming the previous affiliate, WTRF-TV. Smaller markets like Yuma, Arizona, had to wait for many years to obtain another local NBC affiliate.

Following Silverman's tenure at NBC, several affiliates returned to the network, including those in Baltimore, Columbia, Dayton, Jacksonville, Savannah, and Temple. However, some stations switched to other networks: El Dorado became a full-time Fox affiliate, Green Bay joined CBS, and Bakersfield affiliated with ABC. KOTA calls remained on a Gray Television-owned station in Rapid City after President Jimmy Carter's actions in the U.S. This realignment occurred as NBC had previously faced challenges due to affiliates switching to ABC and CBS, to which they responded by partnering with UHF stations in various markets.

After the 1980 Summer Olympics, NBC, which had obtained the broadcast rights for 150 hours of coverage at a cost of $87 million, decided to cancel its planned broadcasts due to several affiliates switching to other networks. This decision, made to promote NBC's new fall shows and generate $170 million in advertising revenue, raised concerns about the network's future and resulted in harsh criticism from the press and even some internal sources within NBC. This all happened in the context of NBC's previous struggles with affiliates switching to ABC and CBS, which led the network to collaborate with UHF stations in various markets.

Following NBC's cancellation of Olympic coverage to air new fall shows and generate revenue, the company behind the "Proud as a Peacock" campaign created a parody song, "Loud as a Peacock," blaming NBC executive Fred Silverman for the network's issues. The song was aired on WNBC radio, leading to Silverman ordering the destruction of all copies. However, the song survived and spread through the Internet due to a few remaining copies. This event reflects the ongoing criticism and concerns about NBC's decisions during this period.

NBC executive Fred Silverman faced criticism for NBC's cancellation of Olympic coverage, which was satirized in a parody song and a Saturday Night Live sketch. The sketch, called "A Limo For A Lame-O," mocked Silverman's failure to have any NBC shows in the top-10 rated programs that season. The sketch's performer, Al Franken, was subsequently not chosen as SNL's executive producer due to Silverman's dislike for him, with Jean Doumanian taking the position instead. This event highlights the ongoing criticism and concerns about NBC's decisions during this period and Silverman's strained relationships with network personalities.

After Silverman's resignation, Grant Tinker, a well-regarded producer, took over as network president, and Brandon Tartikoff, previously not mentioned, became the entertainment division president. Tartikoff took over a schedule dominated by aging dramas and few sitcoms, but demonstrated patience with promising shows. This information continues the theme of NBC's leadership changes, struggles, and the introduction of new leaders during this critical period.

Following Silverman's departure, Tinker's appointment as network president led to Tartikoff heading the entertainment division. Tartikoff faced a schedule with aging dramas and scarce sitcoms, but he exhibited patience for promising shows, like the critically acclaimed Hill Street Blues. Despite its weak initial ratings, Tartikoff kept the show, moving it to Thursdays and boosting its performance. He employed similar strategies with St. Elsewhere and Cheers, which, despite lower ratings, attracted high-value demographics, enabling them to generate ad revenue comparable to higher-rated shows. This information continues to discuss NBC's leadership shifts, challenges, and the emergence of new leaders during this pivotal time.

After Silverman left, Tinker's promotion to network president resulted in Tartikoff overseeing the entertainment division. During this time, NBC's schedule consisted of aging dramas and few sitcoms, but Tartikoff successfully identified and nurtured promising shows, such as Hill Street Blues, despite their initially low ratings. NBC experienced moderate success with Gimme a Break!, Silver Spoons, Knight Rider, and Remington Steele. However, its most significant hit was The A-Team, which became NBC's only Top-20 show in the Nielsen ratings for the 1982-83 season and climbed to fourth place in the following year.

The shows, including The A-Team, Gimme a Break!, Silver Spoons, Knight Rider, and Remington Steele, aided NBC in navigating the challenging 1983-84 season when none of its nine new fall shows were renewed for a second year. In a positive development, NBC transitioned Tom Snyder's The Tomorrow Show time slot to 12:35 a.m., introducing 34-year-old comedian David Letterman, who found success with Late Night with David Letterman, which ran for 11 years and laid the groundwork for another long-lasting late-night talk show franchise.

The successful Late Night with David Letterman show, which aired for 11 years and paved the way for a current ongoing late-night talk show franchise, took over The Tomorrow Show's time slot in 1984. Also, The Cosby Show's popularity revived interest in sitcoms, and Family Ties and Cheers, both initially performing poorly, experienced a surge in viewership after being aired after Cosby.

After The Cosby Show's success, Family Ties and Cheers saw a rise in viewership due to being aired after Cosby. This boost helped NBC climb from third place to first in the ratings between the 1984-85 and 1985-86 seasons. During this period, NBC introduced popular shows like The Golden Girls, Miami Vice, 227, Night Court, Highway to Heaven, and Hunter. The network maintained its success throughout the decade with additional hits such as ALF, Amen, Matlock, L.A. Law, The Hogan Family, A Different World, Empty Nest, Unsolved Mysteries, and In the Heat of the Night.

In 1986, Bob Wright took over as NBC's chairman, leading the network to further achievements. A significant milestone was reached in 1985 when NBC became the first US network to broadcast in stereo. Additionally, NBC worked on rebuilding its relationships with previously lost affiliates, like Savannah, Temple, and Columbia, which was completed with Jacksonville's affiliation in 1988.

In 1986, under Bob Wright's leadership, NBC restored their relationship with former CBS affiliate WOWT. A strategic initiative, "Prime Time Begins at 7:30," was launched in the fall of 1987 for NBC's owned-and-operated stations. This package included five weekly sitcoms from different production companies, such as Paramount Television's Marblehead Manor, airing on Mondays, and Lorimar-Telepictures' She's the Sheriff, airing on Tuesdays. These shows were part of NBC's efforts to strengthen its programming.

In 1987, NBC, led by Bob Wright, introduced a strategy called "Prime Time Begins at 7:30" for its owned-stations. This initiative featured sitcoms from various production companies, such as Lorimar-Telepictures' "She's the Sheriff," which starred Suzanne Somers as a widowed sheriff, and MCA Television's "Out of This World," which featured Maureen Flannigan as a teen with supernatural abilities due to her alien father. These shows were part of NBC's endeavor to enhance their programming, including adaptations like the one from George S. Kaufman's play "You Can't Take It with You" on Wednesdays.

In 1987, under the leadership of Bob Wright, NBC's "Prime Time Begins at 7:30" strategy for its owned-stations included a range of sitcoms from different production companies. This initiative featured the revival of the short-lived 1983 NBC series "We Got It Made," which was brought back in first-run syndication by Fred Silverman for MGM Television, concluding the week on Fridays. This was part of a broader trend at the time where former network series were being revived in syndication.

In 1986, NBC's "sitcom checkerboard" strategy, led by Bob Wright, was tested on KCRA in Sacramento, featuring a variety of five sitcoms in a checkerboard pattern, including revivals of earlier cancelled network shows like Mama's Family and It's a Living. This initiative aimed to draw viewers to NBC stations in the 8:00 p.m. time slot, which was part of a broader trend of reviving former network series in first-run syndication.

The "sitcom checkerboard" strategy on NBC, headed by Bob Wright, was initiated in 1986 in response to the FCC's relaxation of the Prime Time Access Rule and the Financial Interest and Syndication Rules. This allowed networks to air network shows in the 7:00 p.m. (Eastern) time slot, previously reserved for local or syndicated content, and enabled networks to produce content from their own syndication units to fill the slot. This strategy was first tested on KCRA in Sacramento and featured a variety of five sitcoms in a checkerboard pattern, including revivals of earlier cancelled network shows.

In the initial implementation of the "sitcom checkerboard" strategy on NBC, a set of five sitcoms were introduced in the 7:00 p.m. (Eastern) time slot, following the FCC's relaxation of certain rules. However, these shows often underperformed compared to popular syndicated game shows like Wheel of Fortune, Jeopardy!, and Hollywood Squares. Among the five series, only Out of This World persisted for three more seasons, primarily airing on weekends, while the others, including Marblehead Manor, We Got It Made, You Can't Take It With You, and She's the Sheriff, were cancelled within a year or two.

In the first implementation of the "sitcom checkerboard" strategy on NBC, five new sitcoms were introduced at the 7:00 p.m. (Eastern) time slot, but they struggled to compete with popular game shows. Only one show, Out of This World, continued for three more seasons, mainly airing on weekends. In 1987, NBC aimed to boost its in-house productions, including half-hour dramedies, and tested a new sitcom lineup for Thanksgiving weekend, featuring Night Court, Beverly Hills Buntz, Family Ties, and My Two Dads. Meanwhile, NBC's daytime ratings were affected by the upcoming spring 1988 debut of the soap opera Generations. The summary retains the information about NBC's sitcom strategy, the struggle of the new sitcoms, the focus on increasing in-house productions, and the impact of Generations on the daytime lineup.

NBC, in its sitcom strategy, faced challenges with new shows at the 7:00 p.m. (Eastern) time slot and decided to enhance in-house productions, including dramedies. They tested a new lineup featuring various shows and experienced an impact on daytime ratings due to the upcoming debut of the soap opera "Generations." Simultaneously, NBC integrated its NBC Enterprises division with NBC-TV and Corporate Communications, reorganizing merchandising, foreign sales, guest relations, and studio tours. Additionally, NBC began its first coverage of eight consecutive Summer Olympic Games in Seoul, South Korea.

In the 1988-89 season, NBC achieved remarkable success with 17 of its series ranking in Nielsen's year-end Top 30, securing the first place in weekly ratings for over a year, a feat unmatched since then. However, this season marked the end of NBC's long-standing coverage of Major League Baseball, which had been ongoing since 1947, as the primary package shifted to CBS for the following four years. Concurrently, NBC was broadcasting the Summer Olympic Games in Seoul, South Korea, and reorganizing its divisions, including NBC Enterprises and Corporate Communications, to improve in-house productions, such as dramedies, and support services like merchandising and studio tours.

After the 1988-89 season, despite losing Major League Baseball coverage to CBS, NBC maintained its success with popular shows like "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air," "Blossom," and "Law & Order," dominating the Nielsen ratings and earning the title "Must See TV." During this time, NBC also underwent restructuring to enhance in-house productions and support services. Notably, former President of Entertainment, Brandon Tartikoff, transitioned to Paramount Pictures after transforming NBC from a network with no shows in the Nielsen Top 10 to having five during his tenure.

Following Brandon Tartikoff's departure from NBC in 1989, Warren Littlefield took over as the President of Entertainment. However, his initial years were challenging due to the conclusion of many popular shows from the Tartikoff era. Critics partly attributed the loss of David Letterman to CBS to Littlefield's decision to appoint Jay Leno as Johnny Carson's successor on The Tonight Show after Carson's retirement in 1992.

After a difficult start due to the ending of popular shows from Tartikoff's era and the controversy over choosing Jay Leno over David Letterman, Warren Littlefield's presidency at NBC improved with the successful launches of series like "Mad About You," "Wings," "Sisters," "Frasier," "Friends," "ER," and "Will & Grace." A notable acquisition from Tartikoff's time, "Seinfeld," had a slow start in 1989 but later flourished on Thursdays after "Cheers," eventually becoming the top-rated show in the Nielsen ratings for its final season.

Under Warren Littlefield's leadership, NBC experienced a resurgence in popularity due to successful shows like "Mad About You," "Wings," "Sisters," "Frasier," "Friends," "ER," and "Will & Grace," as well as the continued success of "Seinfeld" after a slow start. "Seinfeld" ended its run as the Nielsen ratings leader in its final season, a distinction shared only with "I Love Lucy" and "The Andy Griffith Show." Following "Seinfeld," "Friends" became NBC's most successful series, consistently ranking in the top five shows and reaching the number-one spot in the 2001-02 season, making it the latest sitcom in the U.S. to lead the annual Nielsen primetime television ratings.

Under Warren Littlefield's leadership, NBC saw a rise in popularity due to successful shows, including "Frasier," a successful spin-off of "Cheers." "Frasier" regularly appeared in the Nielsen Top 20, earning many Emmy Awards, despite "Friends" occasionally overshadowing its ratings. This success continued until "Modern Family" broke its Emmy record in 2014.

From 1994, NBC, under Warren Littlefield's leadership, started labeling its powerful Thursday night lineup, especially the comedies in the initial two hours, as "Must See TV." This tagline was later extended to NBC's comedy blocks on other nights, notably Tuesdays, by the mid- and late 1990s. During this period, NBC partnered with various stations influenced by the 1994-96 US broadcast TV realignment, a consequence of Fox acquiring NFL rights in December 1993. This strategic branding and realignment contributed to NBC's success with shows like "Frasier" and "Friends."

In the mid-1990s, several stations, such as WBAL-TV, WHDH, WCAU, KSHB-TV, WCBD-TV, WGBA-TV, WPMI-TV, and KHNL, were part of affiliation deals with networks like CBS, Fox, and ABC. These deals were influenced by the 1994-96 US broadcast TV realignment, which followed Fox acquiring NFL rights in December 1993. This realignment, along with NBC's strategic branding as "Must See TV," contributed to NBC's success with popular shows like "Frasier" and "Friends."

In the mid-'90s, various stations, including some in a Fox-SF Broadcasting agreement, struck deals with networks like CBS, Fox, and ABC, influenced by the 1994-96 US broadcast TV realignment, following Fox's acquisition of NFL rights. Concurrently, NBC, led by Dick Ebersol in sports, secured broadcasting rights for three of the four main professional sports leagues, the Olympics, and Notre Dame football. NBC thrived with shows like "Frasier" and "Friends," while NBC Sports gained significantly from the Chicago Bulls' success with Michael Jordan. However, NBC Sports faced a setback in 1998.

In 1998, NBC Sports experienced a significant loss when it lost the rights to broadcast AFC games, ending its 36-year association with the conference and its 59-year relationship with the NFL. This happened after CBS, which had previously lost NFC rights to Fox, acquired the AFC rights. Simultaneously, NBC executive Dick Ebersol's success in securing broadcasting deals for major sports events, like the Olympics and Notre Dame football, was counterbalanced by this setback. NBC Sports' loss of NFL rights was accompanied by the departure of NBC executive, Warren Littlefield, who left to work in television and film production.

After losing NFL rights in 1998, NBC Sports also saw the departure of Warren Littlefield, who became a television and film producer. This led to a rapid succession of three entertainment presidents at NBC within three years. Scott Sassa took over from Littlefield, introducing successful shows like The West Wing, Law & Order: Special Victims Unit, and Fear Factor. Sassa was then moved to NBC's West Coast Division, making way for Garth Ancier to step in as the new president of NBC Entertainment in 1999. Finally, Jeff Zucker took over from Ancier in 2000, marking a series of leadership changes for the network as it entered the new century.

In 2000, Jeff Zucker became the president of NBC Entertainment following Ancier, however, the network's success faced a downturn as its long-held ratings lead ended that year, with CBS, which had previously struggled after losing NFL, taking first place. In 2001, CBS further bolstered its position by scheduling its hit reality show Survivor as the centerpiece of its Thursday night lineup. This marked a series of challenges for NBC as it entered the new century.

The rise of CBS's Survivor in 2001, after it took over NBC's long-standing ratings lead, threatened NBC's nearly two-decade dominance of Thursday nights. Despite this, NBC still maintained the lead due to the strong performance of shows like Friends, Will & Grace, ER, and Just Shoot Me!, with the latter reaching its peak viewership after moving to Thursday night in the 2000-01 season.

During the 2001-02 to 2004-05 seasons, NBC aimed to draw in additional viewers by transmitting certain dramas in letterbox through its analog broadcast, which was an innovative approach for a major network at the time. However, this strategy led to only a minor increase in viewership.

In the early 2000s, NBC led the television ratings, except for the 2002-03 season when CBS took first place. Despite NBC's attempt to attract more viewers by airing certain dramas in letterbox format, the strategy resulted in a minimal increase in viewership. Additionally, NBC lost the broadcast rights for Major League Baseball to Fox in 2000 and the NBA to ABC in 2002, further impacting their ratings.

In the early 2000s, NBC's standing as the leading television network faced setbacks due to losing broadcast rights for Major League Baseball and the NBA to Fox and ABC, respectively. Although NBC tried to boost viewership by airing certain dramas in letterbox format, it had minimal impact. Consequently, the network's major sports programming was limited to the Olympics, which expanded to include the Winter Olympics in 2002 as part of a new contract.

In the early 2000s, NBC aimed to regain its leading position by acquiring broadcast rights for various events, including the Summer and Winter Olympics until 2012, PGA Tour golf events, and the National Hockey League (NHL) in 2004. Additionally, NBC purchased Telemundo, a Spanish-language network, from Liberty Media and Sony Pictures Entertainment for $2.7 billion, outbidding CBS/Viacom. Despite these efforts, the network's major sports programming remained primarily centered around the Olympics.

In 2002, NBC's parent company, General Electric, acquired 80% of Vivendi Universal Entertainment from Vivendi Universal. This merger integrated Universal Pictures, Canal+, and Universal Parks & Resorts into NBC, forming the new NBC Universal. The ownership of NBC Universal was divided, with General Electric holding 80% and Vivendi owning the remaining 20%. This acquisition aimed to strengthen NBC's content and diversify its portfolio beyond major sports programming, mainly the Olympics. The merger was completed in 2003, establishing NBC Universal under the combined brand.

Following the 2003 formation of NBC Universal, General Electric owned 80% and Vivendi held the remaining 20%. In 2004, Jeff Zucker became the president of NBC Universal Television Group, and Kevin Reilly took over as president of NBC Entertainment. However, due to the conclusion of popular shows Friends, Frasier, and the unexpected death of Jerry Orbach, who starred in Law & Order, NBC faced a decline, leaving them with a lineup of moderately rated programs and limited major hits.

After the formation of NBC Universal, the network experienced a decline due to the ending of popular shows and an unfortunate death of a main actor. Specifically, the Friends spin-off Joey struggled in its second season. To counteract this, NBC introduced its first primetime game show event, Deal or No Deal, in December 2005, which was successful and became a weekly series in March 2006.

The 2005-06 season was challenging for NBC, marking one of their worst performances in 30 years, with only the sitcom "My Name Is Earl" making it to a second season. The once-strong "Must See TV" lineup was faltering, as "Will & Grace" also experienced a decline in ratings. As a result, NBC's rankings plummeted to fourth place, trailing behind ABC, Fox, and the leading CBS network, which continued to dominate the rest of the decade. In an attempt to improve viewership, NBC introduced its first primetime game show event, "Deal or No Deal," which became a successful weekly series in March 2006.

The 2005-06 season was tough for NBC, with a significant drop in rankings to fourth place due to the decline of "Must See TV" shows, except for "My Name Is Earl." The network tried to boost viewership by introducing "Deal or No Deal," which became a hit. However, all networks, including NBC, faced audience erosion from cable TV, home videos, video games, and the Internet during this period, with NBC being the most affected. The subsequent 2006-07 season showed some improvement for NBC, as "Deal or No Deal" stayed popular and "Heroes" gained success on Monday nights. Despite critical acclaim, "Studio 60 on the Sunset Strip" lost viewers and was canceled, while "The Office" and "30 Rock" emerged as well-received sitcoms.

In the 2006-07 season, NBC saw improvements with "Deal or No Deal" and the emergence of successful sitcoms "The Office" and "30 Rock," which gained critical acclaim and won the Emmy Award for Outstanding Comedy Series for four consecutive years. NBC also regained NFL rights for Sunday Night Football from ESPN. Despite these victories, the network remained in fourth place, slightly ahead of The CW. Notably, NBC maintained success during the summer schedule despite overall declining ratings.

In the 2006-07 season, NBC's reality talent competition series, America's Got Talent, became a hit, outperforming the 2002 premiere of American Idol in the 18-49 demographic. This show, which is the original of an international franchise, consistently drew substantial ratings during its summer airings, contributing to NBC's summertime achievements despite the overall decline in viewership.

In 2007, instead of scheduling America's Got Talent in the spring, NBC opted to utilize it as a tool to advertise their upcoming fall shows. That year, Kevin Reilly's tenure ended unexpectedly, leading to Ben Silverman's appointment as president of NBC Entertainment and Jeff Zucker's promotion as CEO of NBC, succeeding Bob Wright. The success of America's Got Talent during summer airings, despite the overall viewership decline, played a significant role in NBC's summer performance.

During the 2008-09 season, NBC struggled to create successful new primetime shows, even with the advantage of promoting them through the Super Bowl and Summer Olympics. Among their few survivors was Parks and Recreation, which returned for a second season despite a short first season. Unfortunately, Heroes and Deal or No Deal experienced significant rating drops, leading to their cancellation. A modified version of Deal or No Deal was later revived for one more season in syndication.

Following the struggles in the 2008-09 season, where NBC had difficulty creating successful primetime shows and saw cancellations of Heroes and Deal or No Deal despite their promotional efforts, NBC's then-CEO Jeff Zucker admitted that achieving the #1 prime time position was unlikely. During this time, Ben Silverman left the network, and Jeff Gaspin took over as president of NBC Entertainment. In 2011, Comcast bought a 51% controlling stake in NBC Universal from General Electric, marking the beginning of a new era.

After NBC faced challenges in primetime programming, resulting in the cancellation of shows and acknowledgement by then-CEO Jeff Zucker that achieving the #1 prime time position was uncertain, Comcast's 2011 acquisition of a controlling stake in NBC Universal from General Electric began a new era. GE utilized $5.8 billion from the deal to acquire Vivendi's 20% share in NBC Universal. During this time, NBC's broadcast of the 2010 Winter Olympics in Vancouver saw a 21% increase in ratings compared to the 2006 Games, but faced criticism for repeatedly airing footage of a fatal luge competition crash.

Following NBC's primetime programming issues, Comcast's acquisition of NBC Universal in 2011 marked a new era, despite NBC losing $250 million in ad revenue from the 2010 Winter Olympics. Although the Games saw a 21% ratings increase, it was marred by a fatal luge crash video controversy. NBC News president Steve Capus banned its airing, and Olympics prime time host Bob Costas pledged not to show it again. The loss occurred despite NBC Universal paying $820 million for U.S. television rights.

After facing a decline in primetime programming, NBC's acquisition by Comcast in 2011 aimed to bring about a transformation, notwithstanding the loss of $250 million in ad revenue from the 2010 Winter Olympics. Despite a 21% rise in viewership, the Olympics were tainted by a controversial fatal luge crash video that NBC News president Steve Capus prohibited from airing. Similarly, the 2009-2010 television season concluded with only five shows – two scripted (Community and Parenthood) and three unscripted (The Marriage Ref, Who Do You Think You Are?) – still running on NBC.

Following NBC's acquisition by Comcast in 2011, the network aimed to rebound from a drop in primetime viewing figures, even after losing $250 million in ad revenue from the 2010 Winter Olympics. Despite a 21% increase in viewership, the Olympics were marred by a contentious fatal luge crash video that NBC News president Steve Capus vetoed from broadcast. During the 2009-2010 television season, only five shows survived, including Community, Parenthood, The Marriage Ref, Who Do You Think You Are?, and Minute to Win It, which were all renewed for second seasons. Meanwhile, Heroes and the long-running crime drama Law & Order were axed, with the latter ending its 20-season run, tying it with Gunsmoke as the longest-running prime time drama in U.S. television history. In 2009, Conan O'Brien took over as host of The Tonight Show, and NBC gave Leno a new prime time talk show, airing it every weeknight at 10:00 p.m.

After Comcast acquired NBC in 2011, the network sought to recover from a decline in primetime ratings, despite losing a significant amount of ad revenue from the 2010 Winter Olympics. In an effort to revitalize their primetime lineup, NBC introduced "The Jay Leno Show" to air every weeknight at 10:00 p.m. on both Eastern and Pacific time zones. This decision marked a historic moment, as NBC became the first major U.S. broadcast network in decades, if not ever, to air the same program daily in a prime time strip. The network aimed to provide a cost-effective comedic alternative to the police procedurals and other hour-long dramas that usually filled that time slot. NBC's executives hailed this move as "transformational" and "equivalent to launching five shows."

After launching "The Jay Leno Show" at 10:00 p.m. to revive primetime ratings, NBC faced criticism from industry executives who believed this decision deviated from the network's history of airing quality dramas and threatened its reputation based on successful scripted series. Many affiliates reported a decline in their late-evening newscast ratings. Consequently, NBC decided to cancel Leno's show in January 2010 due to the negative impact on local ratings and affiliate relationships.

NBC moved "The Jay Leno Show," which was reduced to a half-hour, to the 11:35 p.m. slot, pushing the entire late-night lineup, including "The Tonight Show," back by 30 minutes. However, this change had minimal effect on the network's overall ratings. The improvement in the 2010-11 season was mainly due to the growing viewership of "NBC Sunday Night Football." By 2012, the time slot previously occupied by "The Jay Leno Show" saw the return of scripted series.

In 2012, the shows taking up the 10:00 p.m. time slot attracted fewer viewers than "The Jay Leno Show" had in that same hour two years earlier. At the end of 2010, Comcast, a cable and multimedia company, became the majority stakeholder in NBC Universal, with General Electric retaining a minority interest. Coinciding with this change, Jeff Zucker, the CEO of NBC Universal, revealed his intention to resign upon the merger's completion by the end of the year. These developments occurred in the context of NBC's late-night lineup adjustments and the growing popularity of "NBC Sunday Night Football."

Following Comcast's majority acquisition of NBC Universal in 2012, Steve Burke took over as CEO, and Robert Greenblatt replaced Jeff Gaspin as chairman of NBC Entertainment. A key development during this period was the success of the midseason reality singing competition, The Voice, which became a hit for NBC in 2011.

After Comcast's acquisition of NBC Universal and changes in leadership, NBC faced challenges in the 2011-2012 season, with all new fall shows getting canceled and only one midseason scripted series, Harry's Law, surviving for renewal. A bright spot was the success of the reality singing competition The Voice. This marked the third time NBC had experienced such poor performance in the fall seasons of 1975 and 1983.

Following Comcast's acquisition of NBC Universal and leadership changes, NBC struggled in the 2011-2012 season, only saving one midseason scripted series, "Harry's Law," as all new fall shows got canceled. However, they made significant progress in transitioning to an all-HD schedule, except for the Qubo consortium's Saturday morning slot, which NBCUniversal left in 2012. The network's Super Bowl XLVI broadcast was the most-watched program that season, providing a silver lining.

Despite a tough 2011-2012 season with all new fall shows getting canceled, NBC found success with their Super Bowl XLVI broadcast being the most-watched program then, and the Monday night midseason lineup of The Voice and Smash lifting the network into third place in the 18-49 demographic, marking an end to their eight-year streak in fourth place, mainly due to the strong performance of these three programs (SNF, The Voice, and Smash).

After a challenging 2011-2012 season, NBC saw improvement with the success of the Super Bowl XLVI broadcast and shows like SNF, The Voice, and Smash, lifting them to third place in the 18-49 demographic. However, only four shows made it to a second season, with three being canceled the following year, resulting in NBC maintaining a distant fourth place in overall viewership. In the fall of 2012, NBC increased its sitcom lineup, airing eight comedy series on Tuesdays, Wednesdays, and Thursdays. This strategy, combined with the new season of The Voice, the initial success of Revolution and Go On, and the continued popularity of Sunday Night Football, helped NBC reclaim the top spot in the 18-49 demographic.

Despite NBC's strong start in the 2012-2013 season, their midseason ratings dropped significantly due to delayed airing of The Voice's new season and the benching of Revolution until March. This led to NBC ranking fifth, even behind Univision, during the February sweeps period. However, NBC managed to secure third place in overall viewership by the end of the season, with only three new dramas (Revolution, Chicago Fire, and Hannibal) making it to a second season. Concurrently, NBC Sports moved its operations to new facilities in Stamford, Connecticut.

In the 2013-2014 season, NBC's production of Football Night in America shifted from Rockefeller Center to the Stamford facility, while The Voice, Chicago Fire, Revolution, Sunday Night Football, and Grimm continued to contribute to the network's success. However, a new game show event, The Million Second Quiz, did not perform well. Despite this, NBC ranked third in overall viewership by the end of the season.

In the 2013-2014 season, NBC experienced success with new shows like The Blacklist and Hannibal, as well as a ratings surge from broadcasting the 2014 Winter Olympics, making it the top network for the 18-49 demographic. Although the season was somewhat varied for NBC, it ranked second in total viewership, trailing only long-time leader CBS.

In the 2013-2014 season, NBC introduced eight new shows, with only "The Mysteries of Laura" getting renewed for another year. Despite this, the network's existing series, like "The Blacklist" (which saw a slight drop in ratings after shifting to Thursdays), continued to perform well. These factors contributed to NBC securing the top spot in the 18-49 demographic and ranking second in overall viewership, just behind industry stalwart CBS.

In the 2015-2016 season, NBC experienced further success with the debut of the new drama "Blindspot" and the addition of the second Chicago franchise installment, "Chicago Med." Both shows performed well, leading to early renewals for their second seasons. Additionally, NBC maintained its position as the top network in the 18-49 demographic, partly due to high viewership during Super Bowl XLIX. Overall, NBC came in second place in terms of total viewership, continuing its strong performance from the previous season.

NBC faced challenges on Thursday nights during the 2015-2016 season, despite the success of "The Blacklist"'s third season. The network's attempts to launch "Heroes Reborn" and "The Player" were unsuccessful and resulted in cancellation. However, NBC found a hit with the police procedural "Shades of Blue," which was renewed for a second season due to its improved performance in its time slot.
NBC encountered triumphs in the comedy genre amidst the challenges on Thursday nights during the 2

Despite struggles with Thursday night programming, NBC found triumphs in the comedy genre. The crime drama "The Blacklist" maintained moderate ratings, although its spinoff "The Blacklist: Redemption" was unsuccessful. NBC expanded its "Chicago" franchise by introducing a third spinoff, "Chicago Justice." On the comedy front, "Superstore" enjoyed continued success in its second season. The fantasy sitcom "The Good Place," which aired after "The Voice," drew average ratings and was renewed for a second season in January 2017.

In the 2016-17 season, NBC introduced "The Wall" with moderate ratings, set to air in the summer before the next season. The 2017-18 season saw NBC's continued success with "Ellen's Game of Games" debut and the revival of "Will & Grace," which had ended in 2006. The comedy genre remained a stronghold for NBC, despite struggles with Thursday night programming.

In the 2018-19 season, NBC experienced further success with the launch of "The Titan Games," "Manifest," "Songland," and "New Amsterdam," all of which were renewed. Yet, "The Village" and "The Enemy Within" only lasted one season. NBC's strong run in the 2010s began to decline in the 2019-20 season due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on production.

The COVID-19 pandemic led to the postponement of the 2020 Summer Olympics, which affected NBC's programming for the summer of 2020. Despite this, NBC managed to become the second-ranked network in the Nielsen ratings in 2021 and reclaimed its position as the top-rated network in 2022. This information is provided in the context of NBC's television success and challenges.

(Note: The provided text references the book "NBC: America's Network" by Michele Hilmes and the article "The Blackwell Companion to Television" by Marc Robinson, but it does not contain any direct quotes or specific information from these sources.)

The books "NBC: America's Network" by Michele Hilmes and "Brought to You in Living Color: 75 Years of Great Moments in Television and Radio from NBC" by Marc Robinson highlight NBC's significant contributions and achievements in television and radio over the course of 75 years, including the introduction of color television and iconic programs. This information is provided in the context of NBC's rich history and enduring success in the face of challenges, such as the postponement of the 2020 Summer Olympics.
